Moreover, it is without views and does not grasp at views, does not think, is not attached, does not take as a condition, does not practice, and does not discriminate any views. This is called right view.
By means of this right view, what is seen?
Seeing that all worldly beings are deluded and inverted, bound by views.

When seeing in this way, it is called abiding in the abandonment of all views. Even in this right view, one does not think, does not see, is not attached, does not discriminate, up to the view of nirvana and the view of the Buddha, in order to avoid giving rise to all views.
What is called right view?
All dharmas are quiescent and extinguished, with no thought or characteristics arising or ceasing, the same as nirvana.

In the same way, one does not think or discriminate that all dharmas are thus, does not think or discriminate that they are not thus, does not bring them to mind, is neither correct nor deviant, neither grasps nor abandons. This is called supramundane right view.
Why is it called supramundane right view?
This person does not attain the mundane, does not attain the supramundane, having crossed over the mundane, makes no discriminations. Therefore, it is called supramundane right view.

One who has right view knows and sees the mundane world as it is, and the supramundane world is also like this. This person no longer discriminates between the mundane and the supramundane, and cuts off all conceptual thoughts and discriminations. This is called supramundane right view.
This person does not see what is wrong or what is right, and cuts off all mental thoughts. This is called right view.
Moreover, right view means that there are no further distinctions to be made among dharmas. Therefore, it is called right view.
Moreover, right view means to know the meaning of all wrong views as it truly is.

Such a person, being apart from all discriminations and beyond all discriminations, is said to have right thought.

This person abides in right thought and no longer discriminates between right and wrong, leaving all thoughts, transcending all thoughts, and cutting off all thoughts, so it is called right thought.

In the middle of right practice, one does not further discriminate this as wrong livelihood and that as right livelihood. One immediately attains all pure livelihood, and therefore it is said to be attaining pure right livelihood.

At that time, this person is not said to abide in the right nor to abide in the wrong. Why is it so?

This bodhisattva ceases creating in all dharmas, up to not giving rise to the notion of creating in the characteristics of nirvana and buddhahood. This person well knows that all creations are false, and practices the path for the sake of non-creation.

This bodhisattva well knows that effort is not the path of effort, because it does not grasp or abandon. It is said to abide in correct effort.
Right effort means that all efforts are ungraspable, and it means the meaning of knowing and seeing the true nature of all dharmas.
